message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of a harsh-sounding, holosystolic murmur that is best appreciated at the left sternal border and becoming louder with fist-clenching is consistent with a ventricular septal defect (VSD). Aortic stenosis typically presents with a systolic ejection murmur, tricuspid atresia presents with a continuous murmur, and left ventricular hypertrophy would not cause a murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The harsh-sounding holosystolic murmur best appreciated at the left sternal border along with the fact that the murmur becomes louder when making fists suggests a ventricular septal defect (VSD). The other options do not have these specific characteristics.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The harsh-sounding, holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border that increases with hand clenching is indicative of a ventricular septal defect (VSD). Aortic stenosis produces an ejection systolic murmur, tricuspid atresia presents with a silent right ventricle, and left ventricular hypertrophy produces a systolic ejection murmur, but none of them are associated with an increase in murmur intensity with hand clenching.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The harsh-sounding, holosystolic murmur best appreciated at the left sternal border is indicative of a ventricular septal defect (VSD). The increase in intensity with fist-clenching is known as the grip test, and is consistent with VSD. Aortic stenosis typically causes a systolic ejection murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border. Tricuspid atresia is characterized by a lack of a tricuspid valve and is usually associated with a single S2 heart sound. Left ventricular hypertrophy can cause a variety of findings on cardiac examination, but typically does not cause a holosystolic murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location and timing of the murmur indicate a ventricular septal defect (VSD). The increase in volume output during hand-fisting increases the pressure on the left side of the heart, thereby increasing the intensity of the murmur. Aortic stenosis would cause an ejection systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border. Tricuspid atresia would not present with a ventricular murmur. Left ventricular hypertrophy would not cause a holosystolic murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The findings suggest a ventricular septal defect (VSD), which is a common congenital heart defect in children. The holosystolic murmur is characteristic of VSD and the increase in intensity with handgrip (Valsalva maneuver) is typical of a VSD. Aortic stenosis and left ventricular hypertrophy would present with a different murmur. Tricuspid atresia would present with a different location of murmur and other clinical features.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The holosystolic murmur that becomes louder with hand clenching is characteristic of a ventricular septal defect. Aortic stenosis may present with an ejection click, and tricuspid atresia and left ventricular hypertrophy do not typically present with a holosystolic murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Upon physical examination, holosystolic murmur best appreciated at the left sternal border and becoming louder with hand-fisting suggested Ventricular septal defect (VSD). All other options present with different symptoms and physical findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The holosystolic murmur that is best appreciated at the left sternal border, and becomes louder with hand-grip suggests a ventricular septal defect (VSD). The other options do not typically result in a holosystolic murmur or worsening with hand-grip.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The holosystolic murmur and location of the murmur suggest a ventricular septal defect. The increased murmur intensity when the patient clenches his fists is called the “handgrip effect”, which increases systemic vascular resistance and causes more blood flow across the VSD. Aortic stenosis and left ventricular hypertrophy usually cause a systolic ejection murmur. Tricuspid atresia usually presents as cyanosis at birth.
